posts.post_content:
This was discussed on a forum elsewhere: Since he's not legendary, that must mean that Avabruck regularly elects mayors that are werewolves.  
  
Come to think of it, there are probably some politicians in office in the real world that don't compare favorably to an otherwise average joe that goes on an uncontrollable killing spree once a month.

posts.post_content:
Actually, if I'm not mistaken [Stangg](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Stangg) and [Crib Swap](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Crib Swap) are the only cards that make human tokens so I doubt he'll be pumping any human token armies. His flip side would be much better for token-pumping given the amount of wolf token makers lately.  
  
Quite the cool card though, and I have to agree that it's pretty hilarious he's a two-faced politician.

Posted By: JFM2796 (9/22/2011 3:39:56 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Even without the whole werewolf thing he'd have secured a unique and interesting place in Magic for being the first human lord (and not a bad one at that). A two mana lord for possibly the most common creature type in the game? This guy will see play at some point or other in multiple formats and countless casual decks that use him to boost up token armies or synergisticn humans of note (time will tell who).  
Also note that he is not a legendary creature, you can have four of him out at once.

Posted By: TPmanW (9/22/2011 9:45:56 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
This guy is very scary. Imagine watching someone drop Reckless Waif on turn 1, this guy on turn 2, then Kruin Outlaw on turn 3. Bit of a perfect hand, but it's not really that far-fetched, and it turns into a truly absurd attacking team, even if they don't transform. If they do, the other guy's screwed; Kruin Outlaw effectively gets "double" the +1/+1 bonus' attack bonus since it's hitting twice, and it's also giving your guys evasion--including Reckless Waif, your one drop, which got turned into a 4/3.  
  
I love werewolves.

posts.post_content:
A two-drop lord is always good in my book.  
And if you're running human tribal, and your opponent thinks it's worth transforming him to take your Humans' boost away, for the price of not casting a spell?  
Now he/she has to deal with a 3/3 that poops out more 3/3s.  
He's, simply put, extremely good.

Posted By: infernox10 (10/3/2011 7:40:08 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Very Flexible Card  
All "Werewolves" are Humans while they are in their Day form, but it's flexibility doesn't stop at werewolves. If used in a "Human" deck, it makes your opponent practically skip a turn to get ride of his Human effect if he wants to, a +1/+1 to all humans isn't major unless you know how to use it. I can see this running in a ![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol)![White](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=W&type=symbol) equip deck, or some other ![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol) version of a human deck, not just werewolves.   
  
1/1 does not help it's survivability, but very good either way...  
  
4.5/5 :: Not perfect... but very good and very flexible in the hands of the right deck makers. I can see this same card being used in 2 rival decks, with two completely different play styles.
posts.html:
Very Flexible Card
All "Werewolves" are Humans while they are in their Day form, but it's flexibility doesn't stop at werewolves. I can see this running in a equip deck, or some other version of a human deck, not just werewolves.

1/1 does not help it's survivability, but very good either way...

4.5/5 :: Not perfect... but very good and very flexible in the hands of the right deck makers. I can see this same card being used in 2 rival decks, with two completely different play styles.
